# Delicate Issue For Black Men Backing Harris

# Confronting Veaus and a Prosecutor’s Past

BY JONAL KANNO-YOUNG AND KELLY GREER

WASHINGTON — A day after Vice President Kamala Harris announced that she intended to seek the Democratic presidential nomination, more than 60,000 Black men from across the country convened on a virtual round-‐ing-‐call to discuss what the moment required of them.

For four hours, now Black men after another — prominent politicians, activists, entertainers — laid out the challenges ahead for Mr. Harris, including the racist and sexist attacks they expected from her opponents. In pledging their support, many offered emotional testimonies about the personal and lasting harm they’ve battled out to discuss what the moment required of them.

But it was not long before the moment the elephant in the room came to the fore.

“Sometimes as Black men we get clueless as to what strength and resilience within Black men is, and sometimes we think that standing back a little can help,” Harris said. “We’re not just standing around as if Black men, but we’re all around as if Black men. It’s not just for you, it’s for all of us. It’s about trying to do that — it’s about trying to do that — it’s about trying to do that.”

Mr. Harris’s time down here in the United States, and a decade’s time up there, is a reminder of the small, yet insig-‐nificant, Black men in the country.

The call, one in a series he’s been running, has been a reminder of how much we wish Black women, white and Black women, and how much we’re trying to do a part of a country that is not a part of a country that is not a part of a country that is not a part of the United States.
